column5: I've seen references to the word "rigging" in various posts on Walleye Central and other sites. I've taken this word to mean use of bottom bouncers. I started thinking that there might be broader definitions to this term. How do you interpret the word "rigging"? Many thanks in advance.
To me rigging means slip sinker "Lindy" rig.

I always took it to mean the accessories that were added to the boat to enhance your experience. For example, installing trolling motor, kicker, especially electronics, ie; linking the graphs and the trolling motor. Rod holders, ect. Just anything that you added after the fact. However, I could be completely full of it.
Riggin means to me tying knots and adding something to your line.
As a technique, aka Lindy rigging. Same relationship as bouncing has to pulling bottom bouncers, jigging is jig fishing as a casting and retrieving or lift and drop technique.
As a walleye fishing technique, I believe it began as an abbreviation for Lindy rigging, but probably has evolved to mean different things to different people.

All kidding aside, bottom bouncing is just that, bottom bouncing. Riggin`is the use of a slip sinker (lindy style or otherwise) attached to your main line, above a swivel and leader with a live bait presentation - a finesse technique. Sometimes a floating attractor is used, sometimes a worm that inflated to float up off the bottom, sometimes just a worm, leech, or minnow.Yes, a lindy rig or whatever has evolved from that.
